verses.text: Then Pharisees and scribes came to Jesus from Jerusalem, saying,
verses.comment: The Pharisees and scribes come representing the religious leadership; this context sets up a teaching on true purity.

verses.text: "Why do your disciples break the tradition of the elders? For they do not wash their hands when they eat."
verses.comment: The 'tradition of the elders' refers to oral traditions around ritual purity, not Mosaic Law itself.

verses.text: But He answered them, "And why do you break the commandment of God for the sake of your tradition?"
verses.comment: Jesus distinguishes between human traditions and divine commandments, emphasizing the latter's authority.

verses.text: For God commanded, 'Honor your father and your mother,' and, 'Whoever curses father or mother must surely die.'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes the Decalogue, affirming Old Testament moral law remains binding.

verses.text: But you say, 'If anyone tells his father or his mother, "What you would have gained from me is given to God,"
verses.comment: Jesus addresses the practice of 'Corban'—dedicating wealth to God in a way that excuses one from supporting parents.

verses.text: then he need not honor his father.' By this you make void the word of God for the sake of your tradition.
verses.comment: Jesus upholds the permanence of God's commandments over any human tradition.

verses.text: Hypocrites! Isaiah prophesied well about you, saying:
verses.comment: Jesus cites prophecy as a rebuke; calling them 'hypocrites' aligns them with those condemned in the OT.

verses.text: 'This people honors Me with their lips, but their heart is far from Me;
verses.comment: Focus on internal faithfulness rather than outward rituals.

verses.text: in vain do they worship Me, teaching as doctrines the commandments of men.'"
verses.comment: True doctrine comes from God, not human inventions; foreshadows later Church teaching reliance on apostolic authority.

verses.text: Then He called the crowd to Him and said, "Listen and understand:
verses.comment: Public proclamation signifies importance for all disciples.

verses.text: It is not what goes into the mouth that defiles a person, but what comes out of the mouth—this defiles a person."
verses.comment: Ritual food laws are deemphasized; moral speech/actions matter more. Anticipates later developments in apostolic teaching (see Acts 10:15).

verses.text: Then the disciples came and said to Him, "Do You know that the Pharisees were offended when they heard this saying?"
verses.comment: Acknowledges the radical challenge to Pharisaic authority.

verses.text: But He answered, "Every plant that My heavenly Father has not planted will be uprooted.
verses.comment: Those not rooted in God’s true purpose will not last—see parable of the weeds.

verses.text: Let them alone; they are blind guides. And if the blind lead the blind, both will fall into a pit."
verses.comment: Spiritual blindness leads to destruction; points to the need for divinely appointed guides.

verses.text: But Peter said to Him, "Explain the parable to us."
verses.comment: Peter again acts as the spokesman among the Twelve; hints at his leadership role.

verses.text: And He said, "Are you also still without understanding?
verses.comment: Disciples’ slowness emphasizes need for ongoing instruction from Christ.

verses.text: Do you not understand that whatever enters the mouth goes into the stomach and is expelled?
verses.comment: Physical food does not make a person unclean spiritually.

verses.text: But what comes out of the mouth comes from the heart, and this defiles a person.
verses.comment: Sin arises from within—the heart. Transformation must be internal.

verses.text: For out of the heart come evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, sexual immoralities, thefts, false testimonies, blasphemies.
verses.comment: Echoes the Decalogue and the need for inward renewal.

verses.text: These are what defile a person; but to eat with unwashed hands does not defile."
verses.comment: Moral purity is distinguished from ritual custom. Spiritual cleansing is required.

verses.text: And Jesus departed from there and went away to the district of Tyre and Sidon.
verses.comment: He enters Gentile territory, anticipating a universal mission.

verses.text: And behold, a Canaanite woman from that region came and cried out, "Have mercy on me, Lord, Son of David! My daughter is severely oppressed by a demon."
verses.comment: The title 'Son of David' asserts Jesus’s messianic and kingly authority; a Gentile shows remarkable faith.

verses.text: But He did not answer her a word. And His disciples came and begged Him, saying, "Send her away, for she keeps crying out after us."
verses.comment: Jesus' initial silence tests faith and teaches the apostles.

verses.text: He answered, "I was sent only to the lost sheep of the house of Israel."
verses.comment: Jesus articulates His mission’s priority to Israel, fulfilling prophecy (Ezek. 34:6).

verses.text: But she came and bowed down before Him, saying, "Lord, help me."
verses.comment: Her humble worship is an example of persevering faith.

verses.text: He answered, "It is not right to take the children’s bread and throw it to the dogs."
verses.comment: ‘Children’ refers to Israel, ‘dogs’ to Gentiles — standard Jewish metaphor. Not an insult, but a statement of mission order.

verses.text: But she said, "Yes, Lord, yet even the dogs eat the crumbs that fall from their masters’ table."
verses.comment: Her faith and humility foreshadow the later inclusion of the Gentiles into the covenant through Christ’s Church.

verses.text: Then Jesus answered her, "O woman, great is your faith! Let it be to you as you desire." And her daughter was healed from that hour.
verses.comment: Jesus rewards her persistent faith. Healing here is both a sign and fulfills Isaiah’s vision of the nations seeking God (Isa. 56:6-8).

verses.text: And Jesus went on from there and passed along the Sea of Galilee. And He went up on the mountain and sat down there.
verses.comment: The mountain setting reflects authority—like Moses in Exodus, Jesus teaches and acts with divine authority.

verses.text: Great crowds came to Him, bringing with them the lame, the blind, the crippled, the mute, and many others, and they placed them at His feet, and He healed them.
verses.comment: Jesus’s miracles fulfill the messianic prophecies of healing (Isa. 35:5-6).

verses.text: So the crowd was amazed when they saw the mute speaking, the crippled restored, the lame walking, and the blind seeing. And they glorified the God of Israel.
verses.comment: Public healings as signs of messianic fulfillment; their response shows the recognition of God’s hand working through Jesus.

verses.text: Then Jesus called His disciples to Him and said, "I have compassion on the crowd because they have continued with Me now three days and have nothing to eat. I do not want to send them away hungry, lest they faint on the way."
verses.comment: Jesus’s compassion repeats the miraculous feeding theme, connecting Himself as provider for His people much like God provided manna (Ex. 16).

verses.text: The disciples said to Him, "Where are we to get enough bread in such a desolate place to feed so great a crowd?"
verses.comment: Echoes their uncertainty at the previous feeding miracle, showing continuing need for faith.

verses.text: And Jesus said to them, "How many loaves do you have?" They said, "Seven, and a few small fish."
verses.comment: The number seven often signifies completeness in biblical symbolism.

verses.text: And He commanded the crowd to sit down on the ground.
verses.comment: His command reveals authority over the people, echoing Moses’s leadership in the wilderness.

verses.text: He took the seven loaves and the fish, and after giving thanks, He broke them and gave them to the disciples, and the disciples gave them to the crowds.
verses.comment: The actions—taking, giving thanks, breaking, giving—prefigure the institution of the Eucharist at the Last Supper.

verses.text: And they all ate and were satisfied. And they took up seven baskets full of the leftover pieces.
verses.comment: The abundance left over points to the superabundant grace Christ gives, hinting at the endless spiritual provision to come.

verses.text: Those who ate were four thousand men, besides women and children.
verses.comment: Note that the number likely refers to heads of households, so the full crowd was considerably larger.

verses.text: And after sending away the crowds, Jesus got into the boat and went to the region of Magadan.
verses.comment: Magadan is likely the region also called Magdala, on the western shore of Galilee—site of further ministry.
